dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY HUTCHINSON, 44, confident, full of ambition, and i his underwear, grooms himself for work while listening to motivational PODCAST through headphones.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, (PODCAST)
dialogues.text: You want to reach the top of the ladder, my friend? Then grab your balls and take no prisoners. It’s kill or be killed... Harvey poses in the mirror like a gunslinger. He quick dr one hand like a pistol, grabs his balls with the other, t pulls the imaginary trigger.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Bam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's dressed for success and lookin’ sharp. He approa his SON’S BEDROOM, sniffs the air and stops. He holds his nose to block the smell and enters without a knock. INT. HUTCH’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS A disaster area. Dirty clothes and fast food wrappers lit the floor. FHM girls and NASCAR posters cover the walls. Harvey spots the source of the stink in the corner. A MOL BUG INFESTED, BURRITO SUPREME.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hutch! I told you to clean this room and not to leave food- He YANKS back the blanket. But Hutch’s bed is empty. Harvey looks over to see the family dog, RACHAEL RAY, a portly pug, scarfing down the moldy burrito remains.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Rachael Ray, NO! That’s disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey comes down the stairs. His blossoming daughter, NI HUTCHINSON, 14, sits on the couch, working on her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Morning, Nic.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Hey. He notices her t-shirt: A billiard rack with “NICE” in th middle.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You leave the house in that shirt, you’re grounded for life.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Why? It just means I’m good at shooting pool. He gives her a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Are you going to help me with my video project for school like you keep promising?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You need to get the VHS tapes transferred to your computer like I told you. She points to her laptop.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Done. A week ago. Like I told you yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Good. We’1l work on it Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. And I’m banging the Jonas Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Watch your mouth. From the kitchen comes MARILYN HUTCHINSON, 42, attentive and real estate agent. She hands Harvey a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Running late. Where’s Hutch?

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: He’s not in his room. And I’ve told him a dozen times not to leave food in there, it smells like Tijuana. Nicole comments on the transferred video on her computer.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Nice hair in the 80’s, Mom. You look John Mayer.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Everyone’s hair was bad in the 80's, Nic. (to Harvey) Dinner?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Working late. Don’t wait.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Remember our talk about balance?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: That’s why I have you. He gives her a quick kiss and is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey spots a MILLER BEER CAN on the lawn...and then another, and another. The trail of cans lead to the POOL where Harvey sees... HUTCH HUTCHINSON, 21, a soon-to-be college junior disguis as a shaggy mess of a slacker, is PASSED OUT ON A RAFT in clothes from the night before. Harvey grabs the pool skimmer and FLIPS THE RAFT, DUMPING HUTCH INTO THE WATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: That was not cool, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Neither are the maggots living in your room. He tosses an empty Miller can at Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Or you bringing the competition into my home.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: They were out of Hibrau.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be drinking anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Then start acting like it. Harvey glances over at his prized ROSE BUSHES.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: My babies look dry. Tell me you're sticking to the watering schedule?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: C'mon. Can you stop harassing me about everything?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I'm the boss. Someday you'll have a kid then you’1l be the boss. Until then I need you to pick up lawn bags and a new rake at the hardware store.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I don’t have any cash.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Shocker. Harvey takes out his wallet and hands Hutch his Am-Ex car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s get on it. And don’t use the card for anything else, got me? Harvey gives him a condescending grin, then heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hustle and bustle of a mid-size brewery in action. FACTORY WORKERS and EXECS showing up to work. - BREWMASTE tasting their mixture. - Bottles filled and capped on the assembly line. - A FORKLIFT DRIVER hauls cases of Hibrau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey parks his Lincoln Navigator in the huge lot. As he walks through the rows, he stops to admire the high European sedans in the “RESERVED EXECUTIVE PARKING” secti Near the main building, Harvey stops at a statue of OLD- JONES, a guy from the 1880's. He's sporting a top hat and tails and holding up a bottle of Hibrau. A plaque reads: “HIBRAU LAGER - MILWAUKEE’S LOYAL FRIEND SINCE 1883”.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (grabbing his balls) You and me, Jonesy. We take no prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey zigzags through a maze of cubicles. Promotional displays and test market products are scattered everywher Outside his modest office, he’s greeted by his assistant, JANIS, 50.

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Hutchinson.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Good morning, Janis. Third quarter sales report? She hands it to him. He flips to the last page.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Ouch. Shit is going to hit the fan. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But like The Donald says, “Sometimes by losing a battle you find a new way to win the war.”

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Staff meeting’s in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Bring it on. He tucks the sales report under his arm and heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CEO, ARTHUR BRACKEN, 64, a tough as nails silver fox, pac around the conference table that includes Harvey and the of the marketing department. They are listening to Senior V.P. of Sales, ELMER WINTHORPE, 60. Winthorpe points to a MOCK-UP AD of Old-Jones, wearing hi top-hat, in front of a fire with a cat curled up on his l

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: And then Old-Jones says, “What do you think, Pussy? Shall we crack open another Hibrau? And then the cat says, “One loyal friend deserves another.” Bracken rubs his temples. Frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: The cat talks?

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: He says, “One loyal friend deserves another.”

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Has Old-Jones gone senile? Is that why he talks to a cat?

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Old-Jones, the iconic symbol of the Hibrau Brewing company, is having a conversation with a cat, so I’m assuming he’s developed Alzheimer's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, no, the uh...

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Shut up, Winthorpe! And we're wondering why sales are off twenty percent? Does anyone here have any good ideas, for God’s sake? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: HELLO
dialogues.text: Harvey confidently stands up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: The cat meows. Bracken stares at Harvey for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Pussy knows what it wants, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: I like it! Good work Hutchinson. Make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the meeting breaks up, Harvey files out. His go-with-t flow buddy, PHIL DAVIS, 40's, comes over.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Gutsy move, Harv.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You want to get to the top? Sometimes you grab your nut sack.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Interesting concept. KEITH PITTMAN, 38, your typical back stabbing co-worker, slaps Harvey on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PITTMAN
dialogues.text: Smooth move, Hutchinson. Better grease up the next kayak to Kenosha.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Pittman, if you’re going to make an insult, it helps if people have a clue as to what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well just remember what happened to the last guy that a took steamer on one of Winthorpe’s ideas.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You think I’m worried about- Winthorpe beelines over. He’s not happy.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Pittman smirks as Harvey fights to keep his composure. INT. HUTCHINSON HOME - HUTCH’S ROOM - DAY Rachael Ray is perched on Hutch’s lap as he and his buddi down cans of BUDWEISER and play NASCAR ‘09 on PlayStation There’s Hutch’s better half and BFF, TEDDY O’Neil, 21. Th book smart, 5 foot 3, RILEY FORD, 21. And GREG WARBURTON, he can rebuild an engine and kick your ass at the same ti

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: See that, Ted-O? That was Jeff Gordon dusting your redneck Dale Earnhardt ass. Riley, hold on to your scrote-bag ‘cause here I come. Hutch's fingers dance expertly over his controller as his Jeff Gordon car motors past Riley's Jimmi Johnson car.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Bitch!

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Sick move, Hutch. Guess there is an upside to you playing this thing twelve hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Jealousy is a very ugly quality, Warburton. But I will admit, if I could major in NASCAR ‘09, I'd contemplate going back to school.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You tell Harv yet that you’re taking the year off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for the right moment.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: He’s going to flip his shit.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Might. But I’ve got my life to think about, right? (quick taps controller) Laters, Warburton. Hutch leaves Warburton’s Kyle Bush in his wake and TAKES CHECKERED FLAG. Rachael Ray BARKS her congrats.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Chicken dinner, ladies! Riley tosses a victory Budweiser to Hutch. He toasts virt Jeff Gordon on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Hells bells, Wonder Boy. He swigs the beer then gives Rachael Ray her share.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: That was the last one. Beer run? INT. WINTHORPE’S OFFICE - DAY Harvey sits across from Winthorpe in his plush corner off

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: Hutchinson, who plucked you from the warehouse at twenty-five?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You did, Elmer.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: And who gave you your first promotion, your last promotion and every damn promotion in between?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You, Elmer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I was just-  10.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: Do you know what Bracken said to me after the meeting? That my ideas were antiquated. Winthorpe points to a decades old logo of Old-Jones.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: I created Old-Jones in ‘72... Winthorpe SHOVES a recent bottle of Hibrau in Harvey’s fa Same exact logo.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: And the top-hatted son of a bitch is still selling beer today! That's not a coincidence, that’s staying power, Hutchinson. Something you clearly don’t have anymore!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Elmer-

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: WE’RE DONE. GET OUT OF MY FACE! Fuming pissed, Winthorpe spins his chair, turning his bac Harvey gets up and shuffles out.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHORPE
dialogues.text: Agggh! Harvey turns back.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Sir? No answer. Harvey closes the door behind him. INT. WARBURTON’S JEEP WRANGLER - DAY Hutch and crew cruise in Warburton’s ridiculously jacked Bronco.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You really should consider joining me, Ted-O. A year off from school could be the experience of a lifetime. No classes, sleeping ‘till noon, then getting lit the rest of the day.  INT. 11.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Uh, we've been doing that all summer.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, but how cool would it be to do it in colder weather? Just tell your pops you need to “find yourself” or something.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: He’s right, Teddy. You’re wasting your time with that shit.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: What, getting an education so he doesn’t end up at Auto Zone?

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Funny one, little man. Least I make bank. Lot of good that diploma’s done you.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: I’m still weighing my employment opportunities.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Bet they weigh less then you.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Warburton, 7-11 on your left.
Hutch and Teddy hit the beer fridge. Hutch scans right pa the Hibrau and grabs a 12 pack of COORS LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I'm feeling like the cold refreshment of the Rockies. Cool?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Lock and load the Silver Bullets, baby. Grab two. He dumps two 12’s in Teddy’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m cashed out and you're up. Teddy searches his pockets. He pulls out a crumpled coupo  12.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: All I got is a 1/2 off ona Domino’s two topping. Hutch contemplates. Then pulls out Harvey’s gold Am-EX.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: The things I sacrifice for us. Meet you outside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 7-11
dialogues.text: A kind-of-cute CASHIER, 21, rings up the beer.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Hey, I remember you from High School. Hutch Hutchinson, right?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: In the flesh. Hutch hands over Harvey's credit card.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Wow, Gold Card. You must be doing well?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Some of us are just destined for greatness. She looks at the name on card.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. Still using Daddy’s card are we?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Uh, Hutch is short for Harvey...in Dubai. I’m half Dubai...a-nin.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Nice try. Hutch GRABS an assortment of crappy counter items includi lighters, key chains, calling cards and chick magazines.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Would I buy all these personal gifts for you, including fifty of those Lucky 7 lotto scratchers, if this wasn’t my card?  13.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Seriously? You’re going to buy me all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: If you give me your phone number, foxy lady, this is all yours.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: You're cute. Make it a hundred lotto scratchers and you got a deal.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out by the Old-Jones statue, Harvey vents to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He’s not going to fire you, Harv. You know how Winthorpe gets.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: He was practically foaming at the mouth. Ungrateful S.0O.B. is lucky I saved his ass in that meeting. Harvey looks up at Old-Jones. Has a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You know what? I’m done being bullied. I’m marching into Winthorpe’s office, tell him he can go to hell and- Harvey and Phil JUMP BACK as an AMBULANCE screeches to a right in front of them. PARAMEDICS rush out and thunder i the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open. Harvey and Phil step out to see Paramedics at work as employees crowd around WINTHORPE’S OFFICE. Harvey moves in closer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! The Paramedics lift a rigor stiff WINTHORPE off his chair place him on a the gurney. Pittman steps up next to Harve  14.

dialogues.speaker: PITTMAN
dialogues.text: Looks like Elmer bought the farm...but you ran away with all the pigs.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: What? SARGENT HEINRICK, a Nazi-like Hibrau security guard approaches Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. HEINRICK
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutchinson, it appears that you were the last one to see Mr. Winthorpe alive. His last words to you were probably his last words on earth. As they wheel Winthorpe past Harvey, he observes the FROZ ANGRY GRIMACE on Winthorpe’s face.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: He said, uh, “Good job”. Sargent Heinrick makes some notes and follows the paramed Mr. Bracken comes over to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Elmer Winthorpe, he was a good man, Arthur. This is a real tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: (leans in, whispers) It’s a good thing he bit the dust, otherwise he’d be out of a job. Harvey shivers at Bracken’s coldness.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: I’m not saying anything, Hutchinson, but Elmer’s shoes need to be filled and I’ve got an idea of who’s going to be doing the filling. Harvey smiles, quickly getting over the loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey rants like a hyper puppy as the family eats dinner Hutch sneaks Rachael Ray spaghetti under the table.  15.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Of course I’m upset that Winthorpe’s dead. But it was his time. And now it’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: You're a monster, Harv.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You guys won’t be saying that after I become a Vice President. It’s going to change everything.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: That’s what that Cheney dude said. Hutch drops Rachael Ray a handful of pasta. She INHALES i

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hutch, are you feeding the dog from the table?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: We'll be able to get into the Fair Oaks Country Club. Go on great vacations with the other execs.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: I’d rather become a hooker. Harvey's on a roll. Doesn't even hear her.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Nicole, enough.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: And guess who'll be watching Bucks games from the company floor seats?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Jack Nicholson?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Bracken already bumped me to the top of the list for tickets. Hutch slyly palms a huge meatball, tosses it to Rachael R  16.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: You haven’t even been offered the job, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Arthur practically guaranteed it. We just need a little time. Out of respect for Winthorpe.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Aren't you the saint. Rachael Ray RIPS a gas bomb. Harvey glares at Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m not feeding her!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I’ve waited a long time for this promotion and fate has finally arrived. Harvey's feeling good. Hutch takes the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Speaking of fate, I, uh, have a small announcement.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: We already know, you’re gay.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Funny one. (beat) So, I’ve decided to take things in a new direction with school. Harvey sports a big grin.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You've decided on a major! That's great, Hutch. Business or marketing?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Well, neither. (beat) I’m, uh, taking a year off from school.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Ouch. Didn't see that one coming.  17.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Before you go psycho, just listen. This plan helps out all of us. Marilyn puts her hand on Harvey’s to calm him down.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Okay. Since I have yet to clearly define my career path, it makes smart business sense, especially in these tough economic times, to evaluate the various opportunities out there. So why not take a year off, really research this thing, and “find myself”? Then bang! I’m back in school, heading toward a career and a life filled with huge financial rewards and tons of emotional stability. To top things off, you guys won’t have to worry about cash if things get really bad. ‘Ol Hutch here will unselfishly be able to provide for the whole family and we’ll live happily ever after. (like Barack Obama) Yes, we can. Silence. They all stare at him. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Call me when the shit storm blows over. Nicole gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: That's it? That’s your plan?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Well I might travel a little in between the research. You know what they say, “All work and no play”-

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: ARE YOU INSANE? Do you know how hard I work so you can go to college? A luxury I never had!  18.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Hutch, this might not be the right decision.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m just not sure if school’s my thing right now.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell you one thing, mister, it’s going to look really bad that a Vice President’s son is a college drop out! Hutch is put off by Harvey’s comment.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Harvey, calm down. That’s not the issue here.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’ve made up my mind. I’m not going back.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Okay smart guy, what are you going to do for money? Because you're not free loading around this house like you've done all summer.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I already told you, I’'11l be doing research.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: If you’re not going to school, then you're getting a job! Then you'll see how lucky you are to be in college. Tomorrow morning you are out pounding the pavement. No more free rides here, pal. Harvey storms away from the table, but STOPS as Rachael R blocks his path, staring up at him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Go on! Move it, girl. Rachael Ray convulses...then PUKES SPAGHETTI on Harvey’s shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HUTCHINSON HOME - HUTCH’S ROOM - MORNING Harvey enters and BANGS on his briefcase like a drum.

dialogues.speaker: TO GET A JOB...
dialogues.text: But Hutch isn’t there. On top of it, the bed is made. Har shrugs. Maybe he’s getting through to him. INT. HARVEY’S CAR - MORNING Harvey drives to work, listening to more motivational cra

dialogues.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now say it! Nothing will stand in my way of success. I will get what I want.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Nothing will stand in my way of success! I will get what I want. SUDDENLY, in the rearview mirror, A HALF NAKED GIRL pops from the back seat. It’s the CASHIER from 7-11.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: WWWAAAAAAAAA
dialogues.text: Harvey SWERVES out of traffic and pulls the car to the cu

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: The last thing I remember is we were smoking this killer weed.

dialogues.speaker: WHO'S WE
dialogues.text: Harvey sees HUTCH PASSED OUT in the back in a sea of junk food wrappers and slurpee cups. Harvey smacks him awake. Hutch looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Shit.  20.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 7-11
dialogues.text: Cashier hurries out of the car, fumbling with her clothes Hutch leans out the window.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I‘1l hit you later, cool?

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Screw you, loser. I knew you were full of crap! Harvey looks at Hutch and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Look Dad, I-

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Not a word. Not one word!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey drags Hutch over to OSCAR, 50’s, brewery foreman.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hey Oscar, How’s it goin’?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Harvey!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You remember my son, Hutch?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. You were bussing tables at your dad’s BBQ last summer.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: That’s me. Jack of all trades...and slave labor.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Tell me Harv, how are things in white-collar world?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I’m still the same guy, just wearing a different uniform. Hutch rolls his eyes.  21.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Speaking of uniforms, baseball starts in a week. This is our year.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Gonna crush those wimps from Pabst! So Oscar, Hutch here is looking for a job and I thought this would be a great place for him to start. He’ll work hard and you can pay him minimum wage. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: Of course. If he’s anything like his old man he’1l be running the place in no time.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m nothing like him.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: I always tell the boys in the warehouse, if you think this is the end of the road, just look at Harvey Hutchinson. He’s proof that there’s no limit to your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You speak the truth, my friend. (walking off) Put the kid to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey passes Winthorpe’s old corner office. He peeks INS to see painters and carpet guys changing it up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (like a mad scientist) Soon you will be mine, all mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch is drenched with sweat and miserable as he lifts ca of beer off the assembly line and onto a pallet. Musclehe co-worker, Jake, 30's, works effortlessly alongside Hutch

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Told ya this is an awesome workout, Hutchinson. FEEL THE BURN! Hutch can hardly breath. He stops and leans over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, huh. I need a sec.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Well, hurry up. I gotta get toa veterinarian.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: A veterinarian? Jake flexes his arms.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, my pythons are sick! Jake sticks his bicep in Hutch’s face.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Feel these bastards!

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (creeped out) Seriously, I’m good.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: See how thick the vein is? That’s from hauling kegs, amigo. Go on, stroke that puppy. Jake doesn’t move his arm. Hutch awkwardly touches it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m not real comfortable with this.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yo Jake, that your new girlfriend? They turn around to see, ANGELA, 20's, smokin’ hot blue 22. collar chick, sitting in the driver's seat of a forklift. Jake quickly pushes Hutch away. Turns psycho.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (terrified) I wasn’t...he told me to...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: TOUCH ME AGAIN AND I’LL RIP OFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch is about to piss his pants as Jake stares him down a raging bull.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Give the kid a break, Jake. I don’t thinks he’s your type.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Come on, we're getting backed up. Angela forks the pallet and steers toward the docks. Jake eases up, puts his hand on Hutch’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sorry about that, Hutchinson. Didn't want her to think I was into weird shit. Thanks for covering.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (weakly) No problem. You’re hurting my shoulder. Jake lets go. Hutch strains to get a final peek at Angela

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I gotta stop mixing the roids with the Red Bull. Gets me a tad zippy.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Never would have known.

dialogues.speaker: OKAY, YOU READY FOR A TRICEP PARTY
dialogues.text: He throws Hutch a stack of cases. Hutch drops to his knee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice has finished. Harvey and Phil take off their cle

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (like an announcer) Batting third and playing short stop, Vice President of Sales, Haaaarveeey Huuuthcinson.  24. He makes crowd cheering noises.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Promotion’s looking good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I’d say any day now. Harvey pulls a MERCEDES BENZ BROCHURE out of his gym bag.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Check this out. The Mercedes S-600. This baby screams success.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Even nicer with 20” rims and a gun metal metallic paint job. That’s how a V.P. rolls, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch is sprawled out on a lounge chair, exhausted from w Harvey comes through the gate carrying a garden hose.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hey pal, how’s it goin’ in the real world? Are you finding yourself?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (groans ) I can’t feel my arms.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Not too late to register for classes.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Forget it. You’ll never break me.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I like your energy. Use it to clean out the garage this weekend. He tosses the hose on top of Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Roses look hungry. Make them happy. Hutch grumbles as Harvey walks off with a whistle.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole’s working on her video project. Her laptop is hook up to the TV which shows A YOUNGER HARVEY DANCING UP A ST AT A PARTY, circa 1983. Harvey enters with his head in the Mercedes brochure.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Dad, are you gonna help me with this or what?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: What’s that? He’s completely focused on the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Taking me to get a boob job.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: A little later, honey.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: You’re not even listening! I need help with my project. Harvey looks up from the brochure. See’s himself on the T

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hey, I remember that! He does a Michael Jackson move from Thriller. Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Your old man could tear up the dance floor!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Oh-my-God. Don’t ever do that in front of me again. He goes back to the brochure and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn does the dishes while Harvey places some of his freshly clipped roses in a vase.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Hutch has been at the garage for hours.  26.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Good. The new Benz’1l need a clean home.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: You're being a little hard on him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: All for his own good, Mare. Eventually he’1l realize that his butt should be back in school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a mess. Hutch and Teddy sport improvised hoc gear with bike helmets, gardening knee pads and golf club Hutch maneuvers an empty beer can toward Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Five seconds left in the period. Hutchinson shoots...He scores! The can RICOCHETS past Teddy and SMASHES through a window

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Shit, my ass. The USA just won the gold medal! Hutch moves a stack of boxes to hide the broken window th goes to the fridge and grabs a couple cans of Harvey's Hibrau. They crack ‘em open and guzzle.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You'd think as your buzz heightens, this Hibrau piss water wouldn't continue to taste like my ass.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Speaking of ass, there’s going to be a ton of it next week at Fogelman’s barbecue.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Great. I have to work. I’m telling you, Ted-O, this job is ruining my life.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Then quit.  27.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Can’t. Harv will make me go back to school. (veading Hibrau can) “Milwaukee’s loyal friend”, my ass!

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just get fired? Hutch thinks for a moment. Grins.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Show me the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzed Hutch and Teddy are deep into a twelve pack as H pounds away on his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (Reading as he types) “,...and furthermore, Hibrau tastes like watered down near beer and the marketing has no appeal to anyone under fifty. No hot chicks in the ads, sponsorship at sporting events or cool dudes in movies chugging it. Just some lame old top-hat dude on the brink of death. The bottom line is that Hibrau sucks and everything associated with it makes me think of my great grandfather. And he’s dead.”

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: That’s awesome! It’ll get you canned for sure. Maybe even sued.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: And here’s the thing, I’m just telling the truth. Jerry Maguire's got nothing on me. I’m sending it. Company wide. On his computer, Hutch selects the e-mail folder, “all@hibrau.com”, and hits send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janis intercepts Harvey as he heads to his office.  28.

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutchinson, Mr. Bracken just called an emergency meeting in the brewery. The entire company.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Meeting? About what?

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Might have something to do with your great grandfather. The one who's dead.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is filling up with execs, office staff and brew workers. Harvey enters.

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Wow. Ballsy move, Harv.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Huh? Another co-worker gives him the thumbs-up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: What? From the FRONT of the brewery Bracken WAVES Hutch’s email

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Hutchinson, come up here now! Harvey points to himself, “Me?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at that front Harvey scans Hutch’s email. Shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: I had high hopes for you, Hutchinson. I knew you had that something, but this-

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Arthur, I swear, I did not write this email.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I've worked for this company for 25 years. I respect what we represent. I would never say these things.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: I’m puzzled, Hutchinson. The email came from H. Hutchinson?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (leans in, whispers) That’s my son, Hutch. He’s been working in the warehouse. I apologize-

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Well then, it seems that things have taken an interesting turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bracken reads Hutch’s email out loud to the entire compan Harvey stands off to the side, cringing with every word.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: “,..and the marketing has no appeal to anyone under fifty. No hot chicks in the ads, sponsorship at sporting events or cool dudes in movies chugging it. Just some lame old top-hat dude on the brink of death.”

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (sotto) I am so screwed.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: “The bottom line is that Hibrau sucks and everything associated with it makes me think of my great grandfather. And he’s dead.” (he scans the crowd) Where is Hutch Hutchinson?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Hutch hides his grin, ready to face the firing squad and the hell out of there.  30.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Right here, sir. I’m Hutch Hutchinson.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Come up here, son.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (sotto) It’s party time. The crowd parts as Hutch struts up to Bracken. He passes Harvey who shoots him daggers.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (mouthing) You are dead, mister. Hutch makes his way next to Bracken.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: You wrote this?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: And you think you know how to run this company better than me?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: No, sir. It’s just that me and my boys drink a lot of beer and these are just some ideas of how to-

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: It’s brilliant! The everyman’s perspective. Real beer drinkers! Hutch is baffled, as is Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: It’s about time someone has the guts to address why this company is in the toilet! Desperate times call for desperate measures. It’s time to take a fresh approach and turn things around. He puts his hand on Hutch’s shoulder. Looks out to the cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch looks at him, “What the fuck?” The crowd CHEERS. Except for Harvey who looks like he jus got run over by a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey exits the building gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: This is not happening. He stomps into the parking lot, paces.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Definitely not happening. I’m dreaming or hallucinating or ina coma. A worker passes him.

dialogues.speaker: WORKER
dialogues.text: Did ya here about the kid they made a Vice President? Pretty cool, huh? Harvey just grumbles and walks on. He KICKS and PUNCHES a nothing but air, let’s out a few screams. He stop at the “RESERVED - EXECUTIVE PARKING” sign and PO ON IT, SLAPS IT, TRIES TO BEND IT. He’s in a total meltdo He grabs the light post the sign is attached to and VIOLE SHAKES IT.

dialogues.speaker: WHY-IS-THIS-HAPPENING-TO-ME-
dialogues.text: CREAK. Harvey looks up to see that the LIGHT FIXTURE snap loose from the light housing. It dangles by a wire and then...FREE-FALLS...CRASHING THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF TH BENTLEY COUP THAT SITS BELOW IT.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Crap! Something catches Harvey’s eye at the front of the Bentle

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Oh, no. God, no. He creeps to the front of the car. Scans the placard. CLOSE ON - “RESERVED FOR ARTHUR BRACKEN CEO”  32.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (takes a breath) Okay Harvey, calm down. Not a big deal- CLUNK...The LIGHT HOUSING falls and PIERCES through the Bentley’s hood.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Harvey sprints off toward the main building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch sits awkwardly on one side of the table, Bracken an the very corporate CAROL FOSTER, 40, sit on the other.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Hutch, this is our CFO, Carol Foster.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Real pleasure, Hutch. I hear terrific, terrific things.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Uh, about what? Bracken and Carol share a laugh. Hutch awkwardly smiles, really sure what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Look guys, I didn't mean to cause any trouble. How ‘bout we chalk it up to a big misunderstanding and call it day and I’1l be on my way?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Just hear us out, Hutch. Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We're looking at a three year deal. First year at 350k with a 15 percent bump each year. Built in performance bonuses based on sales and market share. Sound good?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’1l be honest. I’m lost here. Bracken shifts in his chair. Clears his throat.  33.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: We're willing to play hard ball with you, Hutch. How ‘bout we start you at 400k for the first year and a very generous expense account?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You're screwing with me, right?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Plus full medical and dental and two weeks vacation.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: As in, “All expenses paid”?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Fine. Make it four weeks and we'll throw in President's Day. Hutch is starting to grasp the situation.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: What about St. Patrick’s Day and Halloween?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: And those wicked Bucks tickets?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: You'll get priority dates for the company Bucks and Brewers seats.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Now you’re talking. How ‘bout a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey heads back to his office nervous and shaken.

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: They want to see you down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Who does?  34.

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Some executive assistant called, said it was important. Something about Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Did they mention anything about a car in the parking lot?

dialogues.speaker: JANIS
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’11 be back. INT. HUTCH’S OFFICE - DAY Harvey enters Winthorpe’s remodeled office to see Hutch sitting behind a new, very expensive, desk.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Pretty sweet set up, huh Harv? I’m starting to like this real world thing. Harvey fumes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: This isn’t right, Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Not right, Harv? Are you kidding? This chair is Italian leather. And check out the killer view.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Stop calling me Harv.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I think “Dad” is gonna sound a little creepy around the office.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I’m still your father! Hutch puts his feet up on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: And now I’m your boss.  35.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You can’t even wipe your own ass. You really think you can pull off this charade?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: It’s what ol’ Bracken thinks that matters. ANGELA, the hot chick from the warehouse, enters with a putter, golf balls, a jumbo bag of Doritos and a Slurpee.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You've met my new assistant, Angela?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: (to Harvey) Hey. You used to work in the warehouse like a 100 years ago, right? Harvey looks at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Here’s the stuff you wanted, Hutch. Hutch takes the items. He purposely drops the bag of Dori

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Oops. As she bends down to grab the bag, Hutch sneaks a peak of rack. She catches him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Do that again, I'll break your arm.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Such a kidder. Thanks, Ange. (beat) Hey, what about the stuffed grizzly bear head and the Pop-A-Shot?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Got it ordered.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Perfect. You're the best assistant I’ve ever had. Hutch grabs the putter and tears open the bag of Doritos.  36.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Now if you’1l excuse me, Harv, I've got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey paces while bitching to Marilyn on the couch. Nico flips through the TV channels, bored.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I’m telling you, Mare, this whole thing is insane! It’s like a bad episode of the Twilight Zone.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: I don’t understand what you’re upset about. A promotion is a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: He’s Dad’s boss.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: You keep out of this, Nicole!

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Calm down, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Calm down? I’ve worked at Hibrau for twenty-five years. Hutch has been there for two weeks. Do you have any idea how embarrassing this is for me? The doorbell RINGS. Harvey opens it to reveal a DELIVERY with a bunch of packages.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: Hutchinson residence?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: I got a package here for a Marilyn Hutchinson.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: From who? Delivery Guy looks at his notes.  37.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: “Dear Mom, you rock the house. Love, Hutch.” Marilyn comes over. She opens the box to find a set of DIAMOND EARRINGS staring back at her. Harvey’s floored.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: These are beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: And this Wii console is for Nicole Hutchinson.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: No way!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: We can’t accept this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Maybe you can’t, but I can! Nicole takes the pen from Delivery Guy and signs. Harvey is pissed, but feels left out.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Are there, uh, any other gifts for other family members?

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Almost forgot. He reaches down to a cooler and pulls out a FAT STEAK.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: This is for Rachael Ray Hutchinson. Rachael Ray BARKS. She runs over and grabs the steak.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: Have a good one. Harvey slams the door. Fumes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: If that kid thinks he can-

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Look! There he is.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: There who is?  38. Nicole points to the television.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Hutch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Milwaukee Bucks play the Chicago Bulls. HUTCH SITS CO SIDE IN THE COMPANY SEATS with Teddy, Warburton and Riley Harvey stares at the television in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUCKS PLAYER falls onto Hutch’s lap while trying to retrieve a loose ball. Hutch helps him up and the player gives him a chest bump. The crowd loves it.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: He got the company seats. I’ve been waiting two years.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Look Harv, he’s waving at us!

dialogues.speaker: NICOLE
dialogues.text: Awesome. Marilyn and Nicole wave back at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN
dialogues.text: Hi, Honey! Love the earrings! Hutch looks right into the camera and gives a wink, almos if he’s rubbing it in Harvey’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch tosses the ball to the ref and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: C'mon, Bucko’s, let’s get back in this game!

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Hutch, this might be the sickest night of my life.  39.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I still don’t get it. How do you go from warehouse bitch-boy to a six figure Vice President? Especially after the email you wrote.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: The world’s a strange place, Ted-O. As they say, good karma pays off. Teddy looks at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Not necessarily my karma. I think I intercepted someone else’s shit.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Dude, whatever works. I could get used to living like a rock star. Warburton points over at a CHEERLEADER looking their way.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Check out the cheer chick with the explosive rack. I think she’s into our stuff. They guys look over. She gives them a little WAVE.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Damn. He’s not kidding!

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Hide your boner, little man. Let’s play it cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch and the guys hang at the employee entrance as the Waving Cheerleader exits. Hutch steps up, hands her his new BUSINESS CARD.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Hey there. Hutch Hutchinson, Vice President, Hibrau Brewery. You girls were fantastic tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m Jackie.  40.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Pleasure is mine, Jackie. My VIP’s and I were wondering if you and a few of your colleagues would like to go to a private party this evening? Jackie grabs two OTHER CHEERLEADERS as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You guys wanna party with these rich dudes?

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: For sure! Riley and Teddy share an “Is this really happening?” look

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Alright then. Let’s roll. Teddy whispers to Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: If you ever lose this job, I swear I will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch and the group are at the front entrance. Hutch swip his key card, unlocking the door.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Alright, party people, let’s do this thing! Hutch holds the door as they file inside. Teddy hangs bac

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: This is probably not the best idea, Hutch, you're going to get your ass fired for real.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: The beauty of that Ted-O, is that I honestly don’t care. I mean, Bracken’s going to wake up tomorrow morning and realize that he made a huge mistake. So, whatever.  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch leads them through the dark brewery. He finds a panel of switches on the wall and flips them, lighting up a row of GIANT BEER KETTLES.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the first stop on my bucket list tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked Hutch CANNON BALLS into a giant kettle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: INCOMING
dialogues.text: He lands with a HUGE SPLASH then swims over to the group they wade around in the beer.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Nice Form, high level of difficulty. I’1l give you an eight and half.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Nine! Warburton grabs Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: I‘1l give you nine. Jackie moves in close on Hutch, gives him some make out.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And I say it was a 10.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I had a dream like this once. Jackie fondles Hutch below the beer’s surface.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Was this in your dream, baby?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yup. How did you know?  42. Hutch winks over at Riley and gestures toward Tiffany. Ri tries to keep his cool, looks her in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: (stutters) I had the same dream. INT. HIBRAU BREWING CO. - HUTCH’S OFFICE - NIGHT Music is blasting. The barely clad cheerleaders dance drunkenly around the office with Riley and Warburton. Hut and Teddy lounge on the couch, smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I swear, I feel like Willy Wonka.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m Willy Wonka. You’re Charlie. Amanda dances over and grabs the joint. She stumbles back puts her FOOT THROUGH THE COFFEE TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: woooo HOOOO! She cracks up and dances back to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Enjoy it while it lasts, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: And you need to make it last forever. Why the hell should you know less about running a stupid beer company than the next guy?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Well, as old Harv says, I'ma life wasting, PlayStation addicted, college drop out that can’t wipe my own ass.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Look at that Mark Cuban dude. You think he’s got a clue? Jackie mishandles the joint from Amanda and drops it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, watch the carpet!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oopsy!  43.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: What if this Bracken guy wakes up tomorrow and is still into your ass? Then what? Poof! All this is, see ya! Hutch looks around the giant plush office, taking in the expensive furniture, the large plasma, the killer view... cheerleader PUKING into the large planter in the corner. Hutch grabs the remote and turns off the music.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: All right, party’s over! Let’s clean this place up.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch strolls in a little hung over. He does a double tak Angela in her cubicle. She’s transformed out of her blue collar wear into a sexy business suit with her hair up.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Wow! You look awesome.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Hutchinson. You might want to consider it yourself. Dress the part, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Good point. I knew I hired you for a reason. This whole executive thing is going to take a little getting used to.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Just go with your gut. If we can make it in the warehouse, we sure as hell can make it in here.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Right on.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: How about some coffee for that hang over?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: It’s that obvious? A little Red Bull wouldn't hurt either'.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Right away, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Sir. I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Yeah? Enjoy it, Hutchinson, ‘cause it’s the last time I’1l ever say it. She turns to her computer.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA
dialogues.text: Now I’ve got to figure out how to use this thing. INT. HUTCH’S OFFICE - DAY Hutch powers through a Red Bull and coffee as he goes thr the weekly sales report, not really making any sense of i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey looks worn. He reads a memo from security.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (sotto) “If anyone has information regarding the vandalism of a black Bentley Coup in the executive parking lot...” Crap. Hutch walks in unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Let’s watch the language, Harv. Bad example.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Very funny. Surprised to see you in so early. It’s only 11:00.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Been here since eight. Already went through the sales report.  45.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Like you even understand it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Well, what I gather is you marketing boys have been doing a crappy job, therefore sales are down.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Okay, that does it. You're grounded!

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well you better work on getting those numbers up!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: And you better figure out how to get to work. I’m pulling your car privileges. That includes your mom’s car as well. Better get those tires filled on your bike.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Fine with me! Hutch gives him a nasty look and storms out for the offic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey tends to his rose bushes at the front of the house A BRAND SPANKING NEW MERCEDES S-600 with custom rims and gun metal metallic paint job rolls down the street. The B vibrates from the BUMPING subwoofer. Harvey looks at the car with envy. Could have been his. To his surprise the Benz pulls in his driveway. The doors open and TEDDY, WARBURTON AND RILEY ROLL OUT.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. H. What’s shakin’? Riley holds up a bucket of KFC.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Drum stick, Mr. H?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Hutch’s. Dope, right? Wish I had a company car. IN SLOW MOTION - Hutch smoothly slips out the driver’s do in his new five hundred dollar suit. He lowers his design shades and looks at Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Like the new ride?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You do a good job with them rose bushes and I’11 let you take her for her spin. (holds out his wrist) Rooooolex. Harvey looks at the gleaming gold watch and snarls. He gr a rake and shoves it at Hutch.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Here I’m the boss. Now get this lawn cleaned up! Harvey heads toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (sotto) AAARRRGGGGHHHHH .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch has changed out of his fancy suit as he and the guy grub on chicken while raking the leaves. Rachael Ray tear into the empty bucket, looking for scraps.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. You can get any food you want whenever you want it and the company puts up the cash?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Yup. It’s called an expense account.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: We don’t get expense accounts at Auto Zone.  47.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: The theory is you're always working or something like that.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: So dude, let me ask you this. If you can get whatever you want for free, why the hell are we sucking off the Colonel? Hutch tosses down the rake.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Good point, Ted-O. Time to step up this dinner party.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: (re: piles of leaves) What about all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sits on the couch stewing. Nicole’s computer is ho up to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV
dialogues.text: -- The family in happier, more understanding times. Harve and Marilyn throwing toddler Hutch back and forth. -- Twenty-something Harvey working his warehouse job at Hibrau. Little Hutch watching Dad load beer.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: When did it happen? -- Harvey and Marilyn kissing. little Hutch and baby Nico jumping on them in mid smooch.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: When did he become the kid from the Omen? -- Eight year old Hutch up at bat. The pitcher throws a c ball and Hutch desperately swings, but misses. Hutch flip off the pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Little bastard never could hit a curve ball. Harvey looks up as a LANDSCAPER motors past the window on lawn mower. A GARDNER with a leaf blower follows.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey runs outside. Five WORKERS are mowing and trimming

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Can I help you with something? The Leaf Blower Guy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: LEAF BLOWER
dialogues.text: Sure amigo, grab one of those bags.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I meant what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LEAF BLOWER
dialogues.text: Cleaning the lawn. Harvey's getting frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I want to speak to your boss.

dialogues.speaker: LEAF BLOWER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutch? He not here.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutch? Leaf Blower Guy hands Harvey HUTCH’S BUSINESS CARD.

dialogues.speaker: LEAF BLOWER
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutch hire us to take care of the lawn. He pay us double. Harvey starts to boil.

dialogues.speaker: WHERE IS HE
dialogues.text: Harvey hears a GRINDING NOISE. He looks over to see HIS R BUSHES BEING TORN APART BY AN ELECTRIC TRIMMER.

dialogues.speaker: NOOOO000000000
dialogues.text: CcuT TO:  49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch and the boys, looking way out of place, roll into the fancy restaurant. They make their way through the crowded entrance and approach the tuxedoed MAITRE D' for a table. Maitre D’ Warburton Maitre D’ Maitre D’

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy. gives them the once over. MAITRE D’ (major attitude) Beat it, kid. Were not hiring.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Excuse me? MAITRE D’ Dishwasher positions are filled. Now you and your cell mates scamper back to where you came from. clenches his fist. Hutch holds him back.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. Maybe there’s another position available? Dish washing for me is just a stepping stone to my ultimate goal. MAITRE D’ And what may I ask would that be?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Having your job. chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Do you think if I work hard enough someday I could be up here like you, lookin’ sharp and being in charge? MAITRE D’ Highly doubtful. starts to walk away. Hutch stops him and points over to some YOUNG LOOKING GIRLS up at the bar.  50.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: See, if I had your job, I'd make sure that punks like me wouldn't come in here and spot those two underage honey’s at the bar. Because punks like me might call the cops and have your liquor license pulled. How bad would that suck? But the flip side is that then there would be a job opening. Yours. Hutch whips out a business card and flicks it at him. Maitre D’ Maitre D’

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: So if you want to keep your job I suggest you lose the attitude and get us a table. scans the card.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: And if you’d like me to replace those Hibrau beer taps with Old Milwaukee, I can make that happen as well. fumbles, grabs a stack of menus. MAITRE D’ Yes, sir. Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys sit at the best booth in the house. The table is overflowing with steaks, sides, and a variety of booze.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Honestly Hutch, you are the man. That was brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: I still wish you had let me pummel that dude. The WAITER comes over.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: How are we doing over here, Mr. Hutchinson?  51.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Pretty damn good, my friend. Bring us another round of steaks. And throw in a couple of those jumbo lobsters.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Right away, Mr. Hutchinson. The waiter scurries off.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: So what kind of stuff do they have you doing over at Hibrau?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I basically try to figure out ways to sell more beer.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Like a bartender?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Sort of, but on a much bigger scale.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Sounds complicated.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Not really. At first I had no clue what was going on. But then I realized no one else there has a clue either, so I just go with my gut.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Just keep doing whatever it is that you do. Warburton picks up his glass.

dialogues.speaker: WARBURTON
dialogues.text: Titties! The guys pick up their glasses. Toast.

dialogues.speaker: GUYS
dialogues.text: Titties!  52. INT. HUTCH’S OFFICE - DAY Hutch is getting into this job thing. He reviews a spread sheet on the computer then makes some adjustments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch gives a power point presentation. The other execs n to each other, “makes sense”. Harvey is miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch sizes up an ad campaign. He pins an FHM centerfold an Old-Jones ad. He steps back to admire it.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: That’s how to sell beer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BREW MASTER hands Hutch a sample. He sips it, then dump out and passionately tells the brew master what’s missing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutch hangs with his former warehouse co-workers, snackin pizza and taste-testing the different Hibrau brews. They’ all laughing it up and having a blast.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is awesome, Hutchinson. WOO HOO! WHO’S UP FOR SOME CRUNCHES?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of Hutch’s office, Bracken shows Hutch the new sa report. Numbers are up. He pats Hutch on the back and hea off. Hutch turns to Angela. They enthusiastically high fi

dialogues.text: Harvey and Phil, in their Hibrau baseball uniforms, walk toward the diamond.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: In all honesty, Harv, the kid’s doing a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn’t even know what he’s doing.
That could be the secret. Maybe we over think things, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Bullshit. It’s all luck.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. People really seem like him. They approach the DUGOUT. The PLAYERS, a mi employees, are huddled around Hutch as he t don’t notice Harvey behind them.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: ...So the gardeners I hired to xture of Hibrau ells a story. They accidently demolished Harv’s rose bushes and he’s crying about it like a little girl. (mimicking Harvey) The bad men cut my pretty flowers! What am I going to do? I need to change my tampon! The players crack up. Hutch is the man.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I thought he was going to lose his shit right then and there. Hutch looks up and sees Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Speak of the she devil. Hey Harv, big ball game today.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (beyond pissed) Why are you wearing a uniform?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Thought you boys could use some help.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: We're fine, thank you. The team captain, Jake from the warehouse, calls out...  54.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yo, Hutch! You cool with playing short stop?

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: That's my position-

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (to Jake) They don’t call me Lil’ Jeter for nothing! Hutch dashes out to the field.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Wait! They don’t call him that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRACKEN and other employees are in the stands. The Hibrau team is on the field with Hutch at short stop. The PABST RIBBON TEAM is up to bat.

dialogues.speaker: BATTER
dialogues.text: Over by the dugout Harvey fumes.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (sotto) Lil’ shit took my position. A LINE DRIVE rockets toward Hutch. HE SNATCHES IT from th air for the out.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: AWESOME PLAY, LIL’ JETER! Harvey kicks the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the bottom of the 9th. Hibrau is down 4-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey pouts, having still not gotten into the game.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lil’ Jeter, you're up. Let’s knock some wood! You’re our last chance. Hutch grabs a bat and heads for the plate. The bases are loaded. Harvey watches from the dugout steps. The Pabst pitcher throws a fast ball and Hutch FOULS it off. It WHIZZES tow Harvey’s head. He HITS THE DECK, almost getting nailed.

dialogues.speaker: FOUL BALL
dialogues.text: Hutch grins over at Harvey. The Pabst Pitcher sets, then throws another heater.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY.
dialogues.text: (sotto) Now strike him out. BRACKEN shouts from the stands.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Don’t disappoint me, Hutch! Something dawns on Harvey. He gauges Bracken’s expectatio Looks at Hutch ratcheting back the bat. The Pabst Pitcher about to wind up for the pitch when...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: THE KID CAN'T HIT A CURVE
dialogues.text: TIME STOPS. Everyone looks at Harvey. Now he’s done it. H shrinks back into the dugout. Pabst Pitcher looks over at his coach. He shrugs, “Why no Hutch glares at Harvey, then steadies himself at the plat The PITCHER unleashes a perfect curve ball that winds rig down the middle of the plate...CRACK!

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Suck on that... The ball rockets past the outfield. GRAND SLAM! Harvey is stunned.  56. The HIBRAU SIDE goes crazy. The team explodes from the du to welcome Hutch as he rounds the bases. Bracken comes from the stands, slaps Harvey on the should

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Nice reverse psychology there, Hutchinson. Had me worried for a minute. Your boy sure can hit the curve ball! Harvey smiles weakly as Hutch plants his foot on home pla His teammates swarm over, congratulating him. Hutch struts over to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: How would you know if I could or couldn’t hit a curve ball, Harv? You haven’t seen me play since I was eight years old. Harvey's got nothing to come back with. Hutch disappears the dugout with the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disgruntled Harvey and the rest of the marketing depart sit around the conference table. Hutch sits next to Brack

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Before we get down to business, I want to congratulate the Chuggers on kicking the piss out of those pussies from Pabst. And especially our boy, Lil’ Jeter.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: It was nothing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Don’t be modest, son. You're a hero.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Well, I have always said, just cook me up a curve ball and I’11 blast it out of the kitchen. The room claps. Harvey bites his tongue.  57.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: As you all know, the last quarter was solid. Sales have been creeping back up and efficiency is at an all time high. Bracken winks at Hutch who shrugs modestly.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: But we need to keep pushing. What do you marketing boys have for me? Phil stands. He holds up a cardboard display of Old-Jones holding a cat in one hand and a frothy beer mug in the ot It reads, “Two friends are better than one”.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: These are going in beer aisles across the country. Harvey presents a mock up of the HIBRAU MOBILE BAR TRUCK, custom semi that converts into a bar. “Hibrau, your frien the MILWAUKEE COUNTY FALL FESTIVAL", is painted on the si

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: We've got the new mobile set-up ready for this years Fall Festival. We'll be doing promotional giveaways and event sponsorships.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Looks good, Hutchinson. Pittman?

dialogues.speaker: PITTMAN
dialogues.text: I’ve put together a new radio jingle for that younger demographic we've been discussing. It’s gonna knock your sandals off. Pittman opens the door. In walks a group of HARD-CORE RAPPERS, dressed like N.W.A.

dialogues.speaker: PITTMAN
dialogues.text: Hit it, guys. The FAT RAPPER starts to human beat box. But instead of freestyling, the other Rappers huddle together and harmon like a white-bread BARBERSHOP QUARTET.

dialogues.speaker: RAPPERS
dialogues.text: “When you’re near the end and you need a friend, reach for the blend that will put you on the mend. It’s Hibrau, yes Hibrau.”  58.

dialogues.speaker: FAT RAPPER
dialogues.text: “Hibrau Lager. Milwaukee’s loyal friend since 1883.” It’s so ridiculous it almost makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: What do you think, Hutch?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: You want to know the truth, sir?

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Give it to me, son.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: We're not thinking outside the box. This is the same old stuff, recycled. If we want to get the younger demo we have to compete with the big boys. We’re gonna need to get in the ring with them.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Arthur, we’ve done extensive market research and-

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Tell me more, Hutch. Harvey sits back, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Look at Miller or Bud. You go to a Brewers, Bucks or Packers game, they’re plastered everywhere. They sponsor concerts, wet t-shirt contests, TV shows and movies. They're so planted in my brain that I buy the stuff without even thinking about it and so do all my friends.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Our budgets are nowhere close to what they have.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Then maybe we need to start small. See how it goes. Mix it up a little and try something new. Bracken likes the sound of all this.  59.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: I‘1l give you people two weeks to come up with new marketing ideas. Impress me with something fresh and unique and we'll implement it. Hutch gives Harvey the thumbs up. He returns it with a sc

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Next order of business. Bracken waves to someone outside of the glass walled conference room. Sargent Heinrick, the Nazi-like security guard, enters carrying a hard-shelled briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Sargent Heinrick is going to give you an update on my Bentley. I will not rest until this scum of the earth is brought to justice. Heinrick walks around the table, white gloving the backs the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. HEINRICK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Bracken. We have some new evidence that I would like to share with you. He pops open the briefcase and extracts a video tape. He the tape into a VCR at the front of the room. A grainy bl and white image of the parking lot appears. Harvey sweats it up.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. HEINRICK
dialogues.text: We have security camera footage from the day of the incident. Initially it was deemed useless due to the angle of the lens. But I consulted with a forensic crime lab and through the use of infrared video overlay simulation, we may be able to identify the culprit. Harvey speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Maybe it was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. HEINRICK
dialogues.text: There are no accidents. He pops out the tape and puts it in the briefcase.  60.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. HEINRICK
dialogues.text: The process will take several weeks and we expect positive results. I’m taking the tape over there this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: BRACKEN
dialogues.text: Good work, Sargent Heinrick. We’1l catch this son of a bitch. And when we do, I'll chop off his balls and toss them into the malt brewer! UNDER THE TABLE - Harvey crosses his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey discreetly follows HEINRICK, briefcase in hand. Harvey hangs back as Heinrick enters the security office.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER -
dialogues.text: Heinrick exits the security office without the briefcase. Goes down the hall to the bathroom. Harvey walks with determination to the office. He looks around. Goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monitors fill the walls. Each one displays a different an of Bracken’s CAR.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Paranoid much? Harvey spots the METAL BRIEFCASE on the file cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are. He GRABS IT and ZAAAAAP! 250,000 VOLTS rip through Harvey He spins spasmodically and FLIPS out an OPEN WINDOW. The briefcase flies out of his hand, landing back on the cabinet. A few moments later, HEINRICK enters. He pulls out his ke chain and disables the security shock on the case. BEEP B He picks it up and exits the office.  61. INT. HEINRICK’S CAR - DAY Heinrick gets into his car. Puts the briefcase on the passenger seat and blazes out of the parking lot... IN THE REARVIEW - Harvey stumbles out of the bushes. He d to the pavement in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's in the driveway unloading some kind of ANIMAL COSTUME out of his car. He’s STARTLED by the sound of a custom car horn that BLAS to the tune of Chamillionaire’s “RIDIN' DIRTY”. He turns to see HUTCH IN THE BENZ waving for him to move he can pull into the driveway. Harvey does so reluctantly Hutch pulls in and hops out. He hits a button on the alar remote and the Benz lowers to the ground and the doors automatically close.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Pretty sweet, huh? Warburton tricked it out. Internet, satellite, the whole nine.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see you’re wasting your undeserved salary on important things.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: (ve: animal costume) What’cha got there, Harv? Harvey blocks Hutch’s view of the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: No! Hutch steals a peak at the GIANT ANIMAL COSTUME HEAD sitt in the back seat.  62.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Looks like someone’s going with the “kooky mascot” for their marketing presentation. Hutch tries to dance around Harvey to get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Hutch! Stop it! Hutch backs off.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, chill. You’re gonna have a heart attack, Harv.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY
dialogues.text: Stop calling me Harv!

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m out. Hutch hits the remote. The alarm conformation beeps to th tune of Akon’s “SMACK THAT”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
